page.title: 18Rearing Birds for Sport
page.content: {Pheasants and partridges}are specially reared for sport on the{Hexton Manor {Estate.}After the eggs are laid they are taken from the mother and go into an incubator for 30 days. When they hatch the chicks are feed on pellets and lettuce for several weeks. Then they are fed on corn. When they are used to corn they are released into large pens. They can get out of these and return for shelter and food in the summer. Many leave the pens until autumn when a lot of them are shot for sport. Some of these are sold to be eaten. The rest are kept by the shooters to eat, and the beaters are given some as their reward for sending the birds into the path of the shooters. The survivors are kept alive to breed for next season.
